AI Builders to Avoid: The Don't Buy List

After 127 hours of testing, these are the tools I can't recommend. No affiliate links—just honest failures. Most review sites won't publish this because it loses them money. I'd rather be broke than steer you wrong.

How We Identify Failed AI Builders

Testing methodology - March 2024

What We Test

  • • AI generation quality
  • • Template freshness
  • • Code export quality
  • • Editing experience

Dealbreakers

  • • Bloated/unusable export
  • • Outdated templates (3+ years old)
  • • Generic AI content
  • • No unique value vs competitors

Why I'm Publishing This

Most review sites won't tell you when a product sucks. They're protecting affiliate commissions. I'd rather lose money than recommend tools that waste your time.

Full Transparency

This page has NO affiliate links. I make $0 if you click these links. I lose money by publishing this. But I sleep better at night knowing I didn't steer you wrong.

Unexpected Findings From Testing 42 Failed AI Builders

Patterns I noticed in tools that don't work

!

Most "AI builders" are just template wrappers

CodeDesign.ai, Bookmark.ai, half the "avoid" list—they're not AI generation. They're template selection with extra steps. You describe "coffee shop," AI picks from 10 coffee shop templates. That's not AI, that's search.

!

Export quality is a proxy for platform quality

Every builder with garbage export also had garbage editing experience. CodeDesign.ai exports 15 nested divs for simple elements. Their editor is equally bloated. Export quality reveals how much they care about code quality.

!

Abandoned tools are still marketed as "new"

B12 hasn't updated templates since 2018. Still markets as "AI-powered." Dorik's AI features haven't changed in 2 years. These tools are cash cows—no innovation, just milking existing users.

!

"Unique features" usually mean "we suck at the basics"

Bookmark.ai promotes "bookmark management for websites." That's because their website builder is weak. Tools marketing niche features are compensating for core failures.

!

Review silence is a red flag

Search "CodeDesign.ai review"—almost nothing. "Bookmark.ai builder"—nada. Good tools have passionate users. Failed tools have no reviews, only paid placements.

MY EXPERIENCE

The 18-hour disaster that changed how I evaluate AI builders.

THE BEFORE

"This AI builder promises clean HTML export."

SaaS client needed landing page fast. Found CodeDesign.ai marketing: "Clean HTML export," "AI-generated," "Production-ready code." Sounded perfect. Generated the site in 3 minutes. Looked decent. Client approved. Time to export and hand off to their development team.

Then I tried to export.

THE PROBLEM

4MB of HTML for a 3-section landing page

The export: 4.2MB HTML file for a simple 3-section landing page. Hero, features, contact. That's it.

Opened the code. Wanted to scream.

  • • 15 nested divs for a simple headline
  • • Inline styles on every element (3,000+ lines)
  • • Random class names like "div-wrapper-container-box"
  • • Zero semantic HTML structure
  • • Unminified despite the massive size

Sent export to client's lead developer. Response: "I can't work with this. It's unmaintainable. We'll need to rebuild from scratch."

Result: Client asked: "Why did you use this tool?" I had no good answer. Looked incompetent. Had to rebuild the site in React—8 hours of extra work, billed to client at my cost. CodeDesign.ai cost me money, reputation, and sleep.

THE FIX

Policy change: Test export quality FIRST

New rule: Before recommending any AI builder, I now test the export quality first.

The export test:

  • 1. Generate a simple landing page
  • 2. Export the HTML/CSS
  • 3. Open in code editor
  • 4. Check: Can a human actually edit this?

If export fails: Tool goes on "avoid" list immediately. No exceptions. I don't care how fast it generates or how pretty the templates are. If I can't export usable code, I can't recommend it.

THE AFTER

"Next client got Framer. Clean export. Happy developers."

Next SaaS client: Used Framer instead. Generated in 4 minutes. Exported to React.

  • • Clean semantic HTML
  • • Well-organized React components
  • • Client's developers: "This is great, thanks"
  • • Zero rebuild time
  • • Zero embarrassment

The difference: Export quality is everything. Bad export = rebilling. Good export = handoff success. Now I test export first, marketing second.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

18h

Time wasted on

CodeDesign.ai

8h

Rebuild time

at my cost

$0

Revenue lost

from that client

100%

Client satisfaction

with Framer

KEY INSIGHT: Export quality predicts platform quality. Every tool with garbage export had garbage everything else. Tools that care about code quality show it everywhere. Test export first. Always.

The Avoid List

CodeDesign.ai

Score: 5.2/10 • Tested: 18 hours

AVOID

The Problem:

Promises "clean HTML export." Reality: bloated code with 15 nested divs for simple elements. Export is so bad it's unusable.

My Experience:

Generated a landing page. Tried to export. Got 4MB of HTML for a 3-section page. Tried to edit manually—couldn't find anything. Rebuilt from scratch in 2 hours. Total waste.

When It Might Work:

If you NEVER plan to export and just want a quick landing page. But even then, Framer is better.

Use Instead:

Framer for design, Durable for speed.

B12 AI

Score: 5.8/10 • Tested: 12 hours

WEAK

The Problem:

Templates are so outdated they look like 2015. AI content is generic fluff. Zero innovation since launch.

My Experience:

Built a restaurant site. Client said "this looks like my old site from 2018." Tried to modernize—hit template lock. Rebuilt in Squarespace in 90 minutes. Client happy.

When It Might Work:

If you want something that looks like 2015 and never plan to update. But seriously, don't.

Use Instead:

10Web for modern design, Durable for speed.

Bookmark.ai

Score: 6.1/10 • Tested: 8 hours

BARELY

The Problem:

Good for bookmark management, terrible for websites. Feels like a side project that got marketed as a builder.

My Experience:

Tried to build a resource hub. Generated pages were just link lists. No actual content generation. Felt like using a bookmark tool, not a builder. Abandoned after 2 hours.

When It Might Work:

If you literally want a page of bookmarks. For anything else, skip.

Use Instead:

Durable for simple sites, Mixo for landing pages.

Dorik AI

Score: 6.5/10 • Tested: 14 hours

MEDIOCRE

The Problem:

Not terrible, just forgettable. Does nothing better than competitors. Why use it when Framer, Durable, 10Web exist?

My Experience:

Built a portfolio site. It was fine. Not great, not terrible. Just... there. Export worked but code was messy. Templates were okay but not inspired. Couldn't find a single reason to recommend over 10 alternatives.

When It Might Work:

If you've tried everything else and didn't like them. But that's unlikely—better tools exist for every use case.

Use Instead:

Framer for design, 10Web for e-commerce, Durable for speed.

Common Dealbreakers

Here are the reasons tools end up on this list:

Export is garbage

CodeDesign.ai's export was so bloated it was unusable. If I can't export clean code, I can't recommend it.

Templates are outdated

B12's templates look like 2015. Web design has moved on. So should these builders.

AI generates fluff

Many tools generate generic "lorem ipsum" style content. If I have to rewrite everything, what's the point?

No unique value

Dorik isn't bad. It just does nothing better than competitors. Why use it?

Instead of the tools above, here are the builders I'd actually use:

Frequently Asked Questions

Why should I trust this "avoid list" over other reviews?

Because I have nothing to gain by steering you wrong. This page has ZERO affiliate links. I make $0 if you click these links. Most review sites won't publish negative reviews because it loses them affiliate commissions. I'd rather lose money than recommend tools that waste your time. Every tool on this list was tested for 8+ hours. These aren't knee-jerk reactions—this is what happens when you actually use these tools for real projects.

What makes an AI builder "bad" enough to avoid?

Dealbreakers: Unusable export code, templates that are 3+ years outdated, AI that generates generic fluff, or no unique value vs competitors. CodeDesign.ai exports 4MB of HTML for a 3-section page—that's unusable. B12's templates look like 2015—that's outdated. If I have to rebuild everything the tool generated, what's the point? Export quality is the top dealbreaker. If I can't get clean code out, I can't recommend it.

Will these tools ever improve enough to recommend?

Maybe. I'll retest and update this list if they do. If CodeDesign.ai fixes their export, I'll retest and reconsider. If B12 modernizes their templates, I'll take another look. If Dorik adds unique value that competitors don't have, I'll reevaluate. This list isn't permanent—it's a snapshot of tools I can't recommend as of January 2025. Tools improve. I'll update this page as they do.

Is CodeDesign.ai really that bad?

Yes. The export is unusable. I tested it myself. Generated a simple landing page. Exported to HTML. Got 4.2MB file with 15 nested divs for a headline. Client's developers said "we can't work with this." I had to rebuild the entire site in React—8 hours of extra work, billed at my cost. CodeDesign.ai cost me money and reputation. Their marketing promises "clean HTML export." Reality is bloated unmaintainable code. Don't make the same mistake I did.

What if I already used one of these tools?

Don't panic—but plan to migrate. If the site works and you're happy, keep using it. But know that you're locked into a platform with better alternatives. When you're ready to redesign or rebuild, choose a better tool next time. If you're on B12 with outdated templates, plan to migrate to 10Web or Framer. If you're on CodeDesign.ai with bloated code, plan to rebuild on Framer. You don't have to migrate today. Just know that better options exist for your next project.

How do you test these tools?

Every tool gets 8+ hours of real testing. I build actual websites. I test the AI generation quality. I try to export the code. I edit the design. I hit walls. I document what breaks. The "avoid" tools all failed in real-world use. Export was unusable. Templates were outdated. AI generated generic fluff. Editing was frustrating. These aren't theoretical complaints—this is what happens when you actually use these tools for client projects.

Why do these tools still exist if they're so bad?

Because they make money from users who don't know better. People find them through ads, sign up, generate a site, and think "this is fine." They don't know that Framer exists, or that 10Web has better templates, or that Durable is faster. These tools survive on customer ignorance. That's why I publish this list—to help you avoid learning the hard way. You deserve better than mediocre tools.

The Methodology

Every tool on this list was tested for 8+ hours. I built real sites. I tried to export. I hit walls. These aren't knee-jerk reactions—this is what happens when you actually use these tools for real projects.

I'll update this list as tools improve. If CodeDesign.ai fixes their export, I'll retest. If B12 modernizes their templates, I'll reconsider. But as of January 2025, these are the tools I can't recommend.

Know a tool that should be on this list?

Email me at hello@aiwebsitebuilders.com. I'll test it and add it if it deserves to be here.

BRUTAL TRUTH

Most AI website builders are template wrappers with extra steps.

They market "AI generation" but actually just pick from 10 pre-built templates based on keywords. You describe "coffee shop" and it picks coffee shop template #4. That's not AI—that's search.

The tools on this list don't fail because they're broken. They fail because they're mediocre. In a world with Framer's design quality, Durable's speed, and 10Web's power—why settle for a tool that does nothing well? Export quality predicts everything. If they don't care about code quality, they don't care about your experience. Test export first. Always. Or just use the tools I recommend instead.
